DOC.HEAD: Michigan Congressman Calls for Drug Decriminalization
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. George Crockett joined a small group of public officials endorsing decriminalization of drugs, saying money now being spent on enforcing drug laws should be shifted to social programs. Federal drug czar William Bennett reacted angrily to the suggestion, saying Crockett and the others are undermining the Bush administration's anti-drug efforts. ``Decriminalization is the only solution,'' Crockett, D-Mich, told The Detroit News in an interview published Sunday. ``Our courts are burdened down with these drug cases and there is nothing they can do about it. And here we are talking about spending additional billions to build jails and prisons to send people to.'' Money spent on enforcement should be shifted to job training for the urban poor, education, health care and day care, said Crockett, whose 13th District includes Detroit's economically depressed east side. Crockett said he didn't have plans to immediately introduce legislation decriminalizing drugs because Congress would reject such a move. Last week, U.S. District Judge Robert Sweet of New York became the first federal judge to publicly support decriminalization. Also favoring decriminalization are Baltimore Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke and economist Milton Friedman. Bennett, director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, cursed when told of Crockett's position, the newspaper said. ``Here we go. We were wondering who was going to be the first'' in Congress to endorse decriminalization, Bennett said. Giving drugs the same legal status as alcohol could cause even greater social and economic problems, Bennett said. ``Alcohol has done quite enough damage, thank you,'' he said. ``And if you want to see people using crack go from 1 (million) or 2 million to 10 million, make it as available as alcohol.'' U.S. District Judge James Churchill, chief federal judge of Michigan's Eastern District, said the idea at least should be debated. ``Decriminalization is not a good answer,'' Churchill said. ``But it is an answer. ... What are we going to do once we get our prisons full and we still have as many drug dealers on the street?''
